abstract: A call from Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase to the Justice Department led to talks that resulted in a tentative $13 billion deal. | The bank’s board remains firmly behind Mr. Dimon. | Norway’s sovereign wealth fund to warn about the increasing computerization of stock markets. | Ignazio Angeloni is charged with doing triage on Europe’s banks.
snippet: A call from Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase to the Justice Department led to talks that resulted in a tentative $13 billion deal. | The bank’s board remains firmly behind Mr. Dimon. | Norway’s sovereign wealth fund to warn about the increasing compu...
lead_paragraph: In late September, four hours before the Justice Department planned to hold a news conference to announce civil charges against JPMorgan Chase over its sale of troubled mortgage securities, Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chief executive, personally called one of Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s top lieutenants to reopen settlement talks, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook. The call scuttled the news conference and set in motion weeks of negotiations that have led to a tentative $13 billion deal, people briefed on the talks said.

headline.main: A Crucial Call From JPMorgan’s Chief
